title: What would life be like without the internet? - Quora

response.answer_text: I had access to the internet earlier than most people (around 1989 or so….the Internet wasn’t really accessible for the general public until around 1995…) Let’s say I wanted to do any of the following: Send a message to someone. Pre-Internet, my choices were US mail, the telephone, or perhaps leaving a note on their door/desk/car/wherever. (Long distance phone calls in particular were very expensive, and usually reserved for business use, or special family occasions such as weddings and funerals). Radio geeks might have access to ham radio or CB for this purpose.Plan a trip. That meant using a paper map, either the folding maps that the AAA or gas stations provided, or a map book like the Thomas Guide. While driving, listen to traffic reports on the radio to avoid traffic jams, accidents, etc.Buy an airline ticket. Either call the airline directly, or a travel agentNeed to look something up? If not in the dictionary or encyclopedia at home, visit or call the public library.Access news from around the world? Again the public library or a well stocked newsstand would have foreign newspapers and magazines.Want to listen to music? Turn on the radio or Go visit the record store. Folks (kids mostly) wanting to save a buck would use a cassette recorder tape songs of the radio or albums borrowed from friends, the library, etc.How about a music video? Hope your cable has MTV (which actually played videos back then!)Purchase something: Either visit a store, or use a mail-order catalog (Sears, Wards, JC Penny’s. etc)Looking for a job, house, etc: Peruse the “want ads” in the local newspaper, or obtain an out-of-area paper (library, newsstand, etc.) for searching farther afield.Get together with other people sharing a special interest, hobby, etc: Either find (or form) a local club and have meetings, or join an out-of-area club and have newsletters mailed to you.

Thanks for the A2A. Moses Maraga gave a very good list: Moses's answer to What would life be like without the internet? But the primary difference would be in the institutions. For example, people get news now from almost anywhere. Donald Trump said that if she is elected, Hillary would let 600,000,000 immigrants into the US in the first week. Never-mind that it would triple the population of the country, people believed it. He just made it up. Without the internet, news would come from the large credible institutions like the New York Times, CBS news… They used to fact check and expose the lying in elections. News used to be a loss leader for the networks. They could afford it because they had a monopoly and were fat and happy. Now it has to make a profit because there are so many competing outlets for entertainment. So integrity in many cases is down the drain. Medicine would change. Doctors wouldn’t be able to review x-rays from remote locations. We would do all of our shopping in retail stores. No Amazon. We would go out to movies. No Netflix. We would play outside. No online video games. We would have to spend time in the library. No Google. While email existed before the internet, it was limited to large corporations that could build their own large-scale networks. Texting is technically not an internet service, but media sharing is. You would send a lot of letters. Maybe occasional packages with videos. They would take days to get to their destination and days for a reply to get back. Life would be slower - more deliberate. No instant (often wrong) answers. I lived 2/3 of my life like that and I was a technology guy. Today’s world is faster paced but often less interesting. Nothing in depth. I wouldn’t trade the internet for a past era, but there are lessons to be learned from some of the limitations we lived with.

I remember ordering things out of magazine-like catalogs. Back then, if you didn’t have a mag for it or couldn’t find a mag for your niche, you were shit out of luck. So if my friends and I ever were fortunate enough to get one that suited our interests, it got passed amongst us for months. This was as much news as we got on our favorite comic artists (Wizard,) bands (Metal Edge/Metal Maniacs,) or even games (GamePro) because, when you’re living in a tiny town, at the height of the “satanic panic” scare, anything the adults deemed “harmful” basically created a little black market in town. If we ordered anything, it took six to eight weeks to arrive. You read that right, six to eight weeks. You think that two-day wait for Amazon Prime is agony or a few-day delay over the holidays is a pain, we had to watch our mail like hawks during the final countdown and intercept before anyone could suspect. Then the contraband music, comics or games would have to be swapped around, sold and generally hidden from view. School was more like a smuggler’s bazaar and any Solos (a term of endearment earned by anyone who could trawl magazines and find sources for obscure stuff that was worth double what you’d pay for it; e.g. Han Solo) would have to conduct cash transactions in the halls, in the bathrooms, at lockers and often ran the risk of teachers or school administration confiscating the item. You didn’t have it sent to the intended person. You had to get paid for your find. If you wanted information, you had to know someone. If you knew someone, you never gave up your source to a third party. If you were a friend of a friend, chances are you were paying big for that Dark Funeral CD. I might double my price on it, but best believe the guy buying it from me and selling to you was going to double his and rake in huge. If you were a really good friend to the friend that I knew, you may not get charged the “finder’s fee.” The internet didn’t really destroy our black market outright. It eroded it. That black market died over time. Shipping times were faster, paypal accounts were easier to set up and the town…well…it never seemed to notice because, by that time, most of the metalheads had sense enough to move out before we were all accused of burning the bodies of sacrificed children in portable crematoriums.

An interesting question in an age where the Internet plays an integral part of everyday life, business and society! So what are the implications of a life without the internet? Well firstly we should ask the question in a more specific circumstance. What would life be like with no Internet if the 'plug' was pulled today? We'll be looking at this topic from this angle, rather than trying to imagine the world without the Internet had it never been invented. Life without Internet - Pulling the Plug on the Internet. How exactly the Internet Plug could ever get pulled is a complicated question, due to the expansive infrastructure that makes up the Internet. It would probably require the shutting down of every server and local DNS around the world. Some people have spoken about a major virus infection spreading through all servers and computers, rendering them / the Internet in a paralyzed state. There is also another wild theory where by the wind generated by huge solar flares will disrupt anything that carries current, from telegraph wires, anything metal, computers, servers etc. You can read about this theory if you Google "Carrington Event of 1959" This theory is said to be predicted by Nasa. Life with no Internet - Personal Users How would having no Internet affect the general personal user? Well apart from every teenager screaming because they can't log on to Facebook, it all comes down to how much we personally use the Internet and what for. Some of us hardly use the Internet, where others pretty much live their life around it! Equally some actually live a completely New Life within the Internet like those who use Second Life. I asked a few people their initial feelings towards not having the Internet, here's what they said; "So many people use the Internet that if whoever banned it from the world everyone would complain that much and so many people would sue them that they would be forced to put it back on to regain all their money, or everyone should just move to the planet mars." Charlotte - 16 "Well, people would have to start talking to each other more, like they used to, and the whole morning chat at the post office will return. Kids would have to used the library to find stuff out instead of using Google, which will get them out of the house and learning to do things for themselves. People will receive letters instead of emails." Melanie - 28 "It would affect me greatly in work because of our regional offices that relay information, policies and procedures to one another quickly. Personally I don't have the time to go out as much as I'd like to and without the Internet I'd loose valuable socialising networks and access to friends and family far away." Debbie - 45 "Boring life! We would not be able to shop online, which helps a lot of people like me who find it hard to get around" Sylvia - 60+ Socialising - Can our Youth Socialise without the Internet? Many of us use the Internet to communicate, especially those in the lower age brackets above 10 years. From email to chat forums, social networks, dating sites and even virtual worlds our demands on the Internet for social communication and networking are huge. So it's easy to anticipate that a life without the internet would force people to turn back to grass roots and socialise and communicate on a very basic level. My worry with this though, specifically within the lower age brackets is will the people who've grown up with the Internet around them be able to embrace social engagement on a grass roots level and know how to socialise? Would this better enhance communication skills and language in relation to studies on how 'Internet slang' has merged into our language skills? Would our ability to meet new people outside our immediate area be severed and thus affecting who we meet, socialise and interact with and above all whom we spend our lives with? How did you meet your partner? Was the Internet involved in the process? Life without Internet - Communication We use the Internet to communicate more than ever and it's become an integral part of any standard means of communication. So with no Internet our means of communication would have to adapt. I very much doubt we'll be sending smoke signals, but letters would fulfil the hole e-mails left and phones would fulfil the gaps that instant messaging, chat and social media created. An increase in posted mail and phone calls would surely benefit our local postal services and telephone network providers, but what we loved about the Internet was that communication was free! So it's a possible exaggeration to assume we'd all crack out the pens and paper, start licking stamps and calling everyone we know. Further more we would probably resort to basics, that remain free and simply go 'talk' to friends and family. Life Speed not Broadband Speed! The Slow Down It's a simple observation that the Internet sped up the world and lives we live. We communicated quicker, we could buy and sell quicker and we could find information quicker. So with the dilemma of having no Internet we'd surely expect the world to slow down, in business, society and communication. Coping with this huge decrease in processing speed would have extended impact throughout the business and society worlds to a point we'd wonder how we ever coped without it. Life without the Internet - Effects on Business Almost all businesses nowadays have some relationship with the Internet whether it's a simple business listing or an online store. What implications would be put upon businesses across the world with the loss of the Internet? Perhaps world wide recession, stock markets would collapse, millions of businesses go bust and millions of people loose their jobs? The impact on businesses that utilise the Internet would be massive and the make or break factor would be if they could survive without it? But there may be some advantages amongst this devastation; as consumers we'd probably start buying locally, enriching our local towns and shops. We'd look for local services and sustain local economies by trading within our immediate areas. The loss of jobs that relate to Internet Business would be hard to digest. Jobs at our local super market working the tills would suddenly be in high demand as well as many other jobs that don't directly relate to the Internet. What Businesses might survive? Many older businesses 'embraced' the Internet and didn't solely found their existence around it, so we'd find a good number of businesses still in a position to trade. They merely used the Internet as an advertising medium or extra virtual shop. As long as they had diversity and a strong customer base they'd adapt in whatever ways necessary to keep trading. Access to Information & Resources cut We all know the Internet is a massive resource directory, full of useful and useless information, all beautifully at our finger tips. So without it where would we find out the chemical compound of silver, or the world record time for eating After eights? Books! Quite simply, we'd resort back to the old school principle of reading books from libraries. It would definitely be harder finding the equivalent information that the Internet can provide in your local library but if you think about it the Internet basically took the concept of a library and expanded it by about a million times!. Life without the Internet - Conclusion Above all we have to remember we got to where we are today without the Internet. The Internet was a technological advancement that excelled us into the 21st century and changed the way we socialised, did business and purchased goods. It paved the way to the future and still has many exciting advancements ahead of it's self. Witnessing the loss of the Internet is probably very unlikely, but either way I'm quite sure as a human race we'd adapt and persevere as we have done for thousands of years. Those who grew up with the Internet well established around them simply can't comprehend life without it. There are however many of us who practiced life before it's time and have experienced a life without the Internet.

Life would be really really hard. I am now used to solving my curiosity instantly through internet. Whenever I have a question, I google it. If I can’t find it on Google, I ask it on Quora or Wishfie, if I want to know something in detail, I browse through wikipedia, if I want to watch a tutorial or a documentary on a topic, I go to Youtube, if I want to get entertained, I log into Facebook, Instagram, Twitter or Snapchat, if I am missing someone, I Whatsapp them, if I am on a vacation, I upload the memories to Google Photos…and so on Life without internet would be dull, I wouldn’t know what to do. In fact, my job depends upon internet. I learn from internet and I connect using internet. I know there are a lot of cons of internet, but it’s like a lifeline. However, some positive things would happen too: I’ll become a little more patientMy eyes, neck and head would hurt a little lessI’d experience the real world a little moreI’ll meet more peopleI’ll have more time in my dayI won’t become a couch patatoMy fingers would be little less tired at the end of the day (because I’d be typing and swiping less…don’t get wrong ideas in your head :)I brain will become a little sharper as I’d have to use it instead of apps :)I wouldn’t be able to find out how many upvotes I got for this answer :(So please…don’t take my internet away!!!

Some of the things that would happened if Internet was not in our life-: A person who is sad,would be talking to his family instead of posting feeling sad on FB.Most of the relationship would be caring rather than being possessive. 24/7 my babu on whatsapp.People would actually watch Television with family rather than surfing YouTube privately.Everyone had a social life not a social networking life.Newspaper would have been the source of News not twitter.People would value relationship because it took them number of long length letters to impress someone. Not some cheap lines from one of those filthy sites.People would put more effort on finding things themselves rather than putting questions on quora. How to get into IITs?Photos would make more meaning then just for the sake of getting likes on Instagram.People would actually want to move their asses rather than surfing online for everything. Amazon,Naukri,Shaadi,Ola.People would be more genuine and real with others,rather then being fake and jerk on Social Media.People would be more valued person,rather than the 3g or 4g network coverage.Lastly,people would have a real life with priorities rather than having virtual life with dual standards.Without Internet there would be demerits too.We all know that-: I wouldn't be posting this answer here.Life would have been difficult.Jobs,School,assignment would have been a tough load of job.Basically we would be reduced to 1/10 of our current efficiency.But "With great powers comes great responsibilities" and the bitter truth is we are misusing this power of Internet.

I never thought that I could do it myself, if I had a choice. But I was of the view that every one should spend atleast such a day once in a while without the net connectivity, and feel what it’s like. I had never tried it. But yesterday the government of my state made me have that experience. The internet connectivity was banned in our state for 24 hours for certain law and order issues. All the internet service providers such as BSNL, Airtel, Jio and Vodafone suddenly switched off their services.  And here is my experience for a day without net connectivity: Newspaper: I read the newspaper for the first time in many days. I was compelled, because the lack of connectivity did not allow me to have the access to the news online. I was always habituated to surf the website and app of newspapers to see the latest news, while the actual newspaper delivered by the newspaper boy at my door step remained neglected without even being opened. But not today.Sound sleep: I was early to bed and had a sound sleep at night. It was because that day I couldn’t follow my usual habit of exploring my smart phone while lying in my bed and reading the social media for atleast an hour before going to sleep. A break from that habit that day kept my mind calm, in turn assisting me in a sound sleep.Silence: It was almost a soundless day at home; because my wife could not take up her usual hour-long video talk with our one-year old grand daughter staying abroad (even as the little one has yet to learn how to talk).Radiation free: It was a radiation free day; because I did not need to carry my mobile phone close to my chest where ever I went.Read a book: The boredom caused by the lack of connectivity, made me finish the reading of a whole chapter of the book Heaven on Earth which I had purchased many long time back, but which I believed I won’t be able to find the time to read till the day of my retirement from job.Rest to the eyes: My eyes got a break from their burden of gazing at the glaring screen of the mobile phone. The poor eyes badly needed such a rest, which they got that day.I wish the govt. could impose such a ban on the internet services atleast for a day every month. Note: This piece was written by me in the month of March 2018, when I was at Ludhiana in the state of Punjab, and the internet shutdown was imposed at that time by the state govt as a precautionary measure in view of a call for Bharat Bandh given by certain organizations.

Being born in the late 70’s the first 20 years or so of my life were internet free. Although I do find some aspects of the internet to be practical and nice to have. I am happy that I grew up without the internet. I feel that it allowed me to have a much more educational, creative, imaginative, healthy, fun and active childhood. Had the internet always existed I do not know that we would have had all of the beautiful monuments, museums, books, stories, pieces of arts, the quality music etc that we have all over the world today. This is just my opinion and I could be very wrong, but I feel that the Internet takes away creativity, imagination and to some extent productivity. Having lived in both worlds, I do not feel that life without the internet would be any worst. Other than Quora I do not have or want social media so it would not impact my social life either. I admit that the internet does bring some practicalities that I do enjoy although they are not necessary such as online banking/paying bills, browsing/shopping and email.

Seeing as I am only allowed to use a device capable of connecting to the internet while I am at work... not much different if it were only me.The internet runs, well, everything. If two computers can network, they are capable of being part of the internet, so they would have to fail. If this applied worldwide... industry would stop. All facets of modern life would be over, and government infrastructure would collapse. Honestly, I would be quite content to regain my freedom.I am fortunate in that my family has a farm of approximately 100 acres within a two hour's drive. Even if our vehicles failed, I could get there in a couple days with what supplies I have gathered. At that point, I would conscript my extended family to begin fortifying our familial land and laying out plans for a self-sustaining, subsistence community.Once construction begins and order has been restored to our little area, recruitment begins with the local residents. Screening for useful skills is a must, along with an acceptance of the newly established governmental body. Oath of fealty may not be necessary, but could be considered.Pre-screened individuals should arrive within a few days, possibly within a week or two. At this point, most amenities should be available for enjoyment again, sans computers.This is also handy for zombie apocalypse scenarios and some other 'doomsday' occurrences. Due to the short amount of time available to me for internet usage, this is not the established plan in full, merely a general outline.

Heaven. Yes, that’s how it was! I went on a Himalayan trek, one year back and I had no access to internet for almost 5–6 days. Trust me, those days were just so beautiful and I remember each and every moment of it. I didn’t wake up to check Instagram updates, instead I woke up to this -  I wasn’t going through my Facebook account, but I was going through mountains covered with beautiful Rhododendrons -  I wasn’t talking to a person who was miles away on Whatsapp, but I was talking to the person next to me, lying on a green carpet with violet flowers -  I wasn’t ogling at some fancy dress on Jabong/Myntra, instead I was ogling at this beauty, wondering if I can really do this -  I wasn’t rolling over my bed and reading inspiring Quora stories on “how you shouldn’t give up”, instead I was rolling over huge boulders and I wasn’t giving up -  I wasn’t going “awe” over some model’s size zero or some hot guy’s abs on Snapchat, instead I was going “awe” over Mother Nature -  I wasn’t getting goosebumps over someone else’s achievement on Youtube, instead I was getting goosebumps over my own achievement. We conquered the peak after 16 hours of strenuous trek -  Though internet is a boon, sometimes I think life would be more peaceful without it. You ask me how your life would be without internet? I say it would be like heaven and this is what it looks like -  Thanks for reading! Cheers!!

My Apartment Neighbor came to me to set up his New Laptop, because he doesn't have internet. Here's the thing, even i don't have internet. I only have Company Phone which has 2 GB LTE, which ends in like 5 days, then even accessing Quora is slow, and can't really play videos. But i was able to put my phone in hotspot mode and set up his laptop, as i still had the initial fast 2 GB. So, there are people living without regular internet. Dont feel pity for i believe i have already seen enough internet for a lifetime. But yes 3 out of last 5 years have been without Internet. What happens when you live like this is that sometimes you know only after couple days who won World Cup or Wimbledon.(and so on) Nor have i ever had cable and haven't read any news in long time. Its latest in series of 'experiments' i am doing.

As we all know that internet has made our life easier , but deep inside we all are being trapped by this network.Its stealing our time and we are knowingly or unknowingly losing our happiness.Its fact to accept that internet had brought great adventure ,it has brought whole world just to our finger tips but still Reality is reality and nothing can replace the actual world where u r surviving.The virtual world can serve illusion of happiness but remember that reality is always true and good. At present words have turned to text ,memories to selfies and conversations to calls.Ask urself are u really satisfied with this ? I feel all are delight of its usage but no one is happy And the relationships are losing its importance .Every random moment the other person seems to be fascinating and The people prioritise their mood based on the feeds found on their pages .Is this life ? Is this the change which had joined wings to our thinking. But ya internet is vitable and had seved us to its maximum extent but life is natural process not a computer programming which needs internet for it access . Be Smart enough internet is invention of man not a man is an invention of internet

Life was great! Friends met in person and valued the quality time spent together. We were more aware of our neighbours and more community connect helped everyone. Expressions were not limited to response buttons. Had a variety of laughter and myriad ways of saying things that mattered. Cards.. those little envelopes mattered a lot. One could actually cuddle on them. Hobbies created tangible masterpieces. Now it’s just screenshots. However, I have had the power to connect with people worldwide and have some cherished friendships built over internet. So many wonderful people who I have never met in person but those who have been adding a lot to my education, happiness, and personal growth met me over different online platforms from yahoo chat boxes to Quora. More to come. Strike a balance between online and offline life. Everything is good, bad and ugly. You are the one to decide what good you can drive and how much you can let it affect you.

I think it’s going to be a mixed bag. It is undeniable that the Internet has saved our precious time but ironically it also wastes a ton of our time too. With the Internet gone, our convenience would definitely take a dive, we are too used to ordering things online than actually walking to a supermarket. Also without email, professional life would take a hit. But, on the positive side, at least it'd revive our social life. People would "actually" meet someone and enjoy a vacation than sharing it on social media. Nobody can really predict what the situation will be like until the scenario actually arrives which itself has a very remote possibility.

My life would be way better. I think my life would be more productive everyday because internet is one the the reasons why I ended up laying in bed for the whole day, before. Now that I am a Mom already, internet somehow helps me because I am able to search tips about motherhood since I am a first time mom. But I realize when your job is being a mom there’s no manual book because everyday you will discover new things about motherhood. I became more hands- on because i depend on my own experience everyday with my daughter. Internet is such a distraction for me because sometimes when I use internet I miss playing with my daughter. i have to reduce using internet everyday. Actually now, I am not active in some social media accounts like facebook, snapchat and etc,.

Horrible. The human race would be extinct, we would have all died from a severe lack of dank memes. Not at all. We would communicate by sending letters by postWe would call a lot more than we do nowWe would be a lot more productive. People weren't as distracted by novels as we are with the internet.Arranging things with people would have to rely on trust - you’d tell them you were going to meet at a certain place weeks, even months before the date and pray they’d showWe would be a lot more social, kids would even play outsideWe wouldn't have dank memesMany countries would still be under developed - the internet has opened many doors for development.The world would still look pretty good, but not ‘we-have-quora’ good.

Life wouldn't be all that different.  People are born, grow up, go to school, form friendships, relationships, deal with tragedies, triumphs, then die.  Same as it's been for thousands of years, and will be for thousands more.    Sure, the way we communicate and get information would be different. The main difference would be speed.  The Internet makes communcation and information much faster. But fundamentally, you are still doing the same stuff.  Facebook isnt enabling you to do anything you weren't doing already.  But now it's easier and faster to maintain relationships, so you can do more of it.  Go to moviefone to check movie times?  It's the same thing we used to do before the Internet except we used to make a phone call or check the newspaper.

1. People will be knowing pretty less about the world.More chances of you getting excited on getting SMSs like YOUR MOBILE NUMBER HAS WON YOU (2CRORES,35LAKHS) IN BLABLA PROMO 2016...  2. People will undoubtedly believe in God's existence. 3. Most of them will be hard workers but not smart workers.  4.Todays smart phones will be slightly more active than its in flight mode.   5. Our moms will be still referring to "how to cook" books sold in various regional fests.  6. Steve Harvey's honest mistake would have gone unnoticed.  In general we would be leading our life just like how they did 20-25 years back but in front of HD TVs, riding modern day bikes, listening to same list of music stored in SD card.

It seems much different when you are not using the internet entire day. Two years back, I went to Kota for engineering coaching and there was no internet facility there and even I didn't have an android device to use it. It seems like it is going to be hell without internet but conversely, I enjoyed more in life without internet. I was more interactive with people, listening to others, feeling for others and also it gave me natural environment like just be with friends and analysing the beautiful environment , watching sky . You can talk to yourself all the time, it will seriosuly increase your mental strength . My life at Kota without internet totally changed me and help me to find myself.

It would be exactly as it was BEFORE the WWW was popular. You HAD to go to the library for any info. You had to look into white/yellow pages books for telephones. You had to ask for information, or order things by telephone. To communicate, fastest way was by telephone, which was expensive to talk long distance. Or, if you could wait, you could write letters, and send physical photographs by normal mail, which would take weeks or more. If something was urgent and did not have a telephone, you had to send a telegram. Most everything else was done personally by going physically. And that’s it. The internet has accelerated our communications and the distribution of information. Information did exist, but it was a lot more cumbersome to get at it!

For nearly 10 months I lived without Internet access readily accessible while living in the poor Ecuadorian Amazon. I was working on college papers and essays at the same time to the limited access was actually nice because I wasn't distracted and would have to plan when I needed the Internet! It was so exciting when I did have access. But going that long without constant access allowed me to have lots of introspection and feel grounded in the world around me.

Life without internet would be a body without heart.Yes,we lived in an era where we had no entertainment and we longed for programs or shows but we are in the world of internet. 1)we get everything what we need at an instant. 2)we shop online,we see movies online and our life has been with internet. 3)without internet we cannot sustain in this world for sure.Every thing is digitalized and everything is updated in internet. Moreover we have google.If we have a doubt on anything we just google it. So there cannot be a life without internet in this digital world.And internet will be our source.

It would be like this. Few pictures only 90s kid can recall. Here is the picture gallery. I hope you will enjoy.              Flames. Uff. How many of you have played this? The Playstore destroyed the childhood, I guess.

Exactly like it did for half my life. We had colour TV, telex and fax machines, public libraries, newspapers twice a day, and (of course) the radio.  It was a World with the Beatles, Paul Simon, Woody Allen, Leonard Bernstein, “Evita”, Kenny Everret, “The Pink Panther”, Porsche 911, Fiery Fred, Pavarotti, and the moon landings.  People went on holiday to the Costa del Sol, on package holidays bought from cut price brochures in shops, newspapers, or off the teletext.

I will go with the 1990 comment. I first got on a network in 1973. I would attempt as I did to leverage data toward the advantage of myself and the people I worked for. The Internet as it is is kind of an accidental birth. The rest of us were waiting for the world to catch up (retire, die off: really). For what duration? I've been off the net for weeks and months at a time. People still live.

You can still find some towns where the Internet isn’t much of a factor, maybe because they are remote and they don’t have high-speed yet, or the cell towers are poor, or people just don’t care that much about it. The people there still use their library, they rent videos, they read paper books and get paper newspapers delivered to their doors. They actually shop in malls. Maybe more of them pay cash. In short, they get along just fine. I think the one thing the Net has helped the most with is helping white collar people start their own businesses, instead of having to work for a corporation.

Waaaaaaaay better. I used to read a lot when I was younger. Besides watching a lot of grown up shows thats were I got most of my information. But then my parents got me an ipod touch. Reading books just didnt happen anymore. The workd of youtube and tumblr came into my life and I was never the same after that. I feel like my life would be better if I just read more and stopped being distracted all the time. I miss being able to read dozens of books. I think after writing this I might try.

1. All big Business corporations would almost come to a stand still.2. Money markets, online Communication, e commerce, for that case any other business who rely on internet will have hard time surviving.3. No online applications that we use for our day to day activities will be available, there by hampering customer experience.4. An Ocean of knowledge base would go unavailable that would affect students from all backgrounds, researchers, technicians.5. Almost nil opportunities in terms of advertising &  finding openings in any organization, with lack of information the probability of getting the right people to work  gets difficult. There by contributing to lower GDP of a nation.5. Hence Overall financial growth all over globe will get delayed that would in turn lead to many economic issues.

It would be different of course but not much, bc when I was way younger I was reading lots of books. Now I got a phone so I got access to Google play books. I dont spend too much time in the Internet. I couldn't have fun in 9gag if there wasn't internet that's all. Even this is my first time in quora.

This is not a question that requires a lot of speculation. Virtually all of history is the story of what life is like without the Internet. Many who are still alive can give a direct account of how life was different. If looking for a more experiential answer, turn off your phone and stay away from computers for a month. You’ll quickly experience much (though not all - because everyone else expects you to be connected!) of what life would be like.

1. People will have weight of books and compact disks2. Interactions will be more amongst people3. Education will once again becomes complicated4. People have to take paper maps and guide books in their hands while they travel5. Dictionary, encyclopedia related books sales will increase6. People can't ask crazy questions or put crazy posts.7. Freedom of speech will be limited within a circle.8. Huge unemployment occurs9. Mass media will be in the hands of few

I can of course live a happy life, to be honest! I rely on internet mostly for improving my intellect. My happiest days are when I live without internet and electricity as I get a chance to go out and make love with nature! I rarely talk to anyone in any given day as I would be busy with my job and in the reading. If not pondering on my laptop (with internet), I would highly appreciate myself for uttering words to my fellow beings living around me!

Without Internet communications might be slower and costly as it was 20 years ago.There would be less sources of entertainment and low progress rate of our country.Economic instability and lack of jobs.Freedom of speech might be lesser than now.I would be outside playing basket ball or tennis.Uhm... have a life

Not a huge change as  you would still have OSI and propriety based systems and maybe FIDO and other BBS systems would still be massive. However the downside is that only poeple like me and Vint Cerf would have cool mail addresses like c=uk/cn=maurice  The rest of you subs would have addresses like 10083:XYZ567 and pay 50p  per email with data charges on top and LIKE it :-)  Btw I am not kidding about having an email at the country level my Boss in BT had one on the Uk ADMD back in the day.
Exactly like it looks now, except maybe with a few less wires and a lot less people wandering across streets thumbing their “smart” phones. Somehow I think you meant to ask a different question.

It's like asking “what will life without the medical advancement be?” The internet is an extremely useful entity. People just stop appreciating it because majority of them don't use it to the fullest and operate just a few social networking sites. To answer your question simply, life without internet would be disconnected.

If it just me who live without internet, maybe its difficult. Because, everyone is using internet now. If they want to contact some old friend how live in other country, they can use intenet. If they want to learn something new in a short amount of time, they can get it on the internet too. Then, if it just me who live without internet? Oh my gosh. bye!
You can see people spending considerable time in librariesYou can see children play in the streetsThere will be people having hardships to find informationPeople will not have required awareness.

In an era where we even get our groceries and other basic stuff without getting out of our homes, it would be quite difficult to live. Though this will improve the social meetings but will gradually decrease the economic growth of 1000's of industries which rely on the online communication with us.  Peace.

The easiest starting point may be to just look back at life before 1990, a time of landline telephones, 9-to-5 work schedules, and normal rental stores. But that historical reality doesn’t really answer the question, because in an alternate history, we wouldn’t have known what we were missing.
I grew up before the internet existed. It was awesome. We talked to each other. We played outside. We used our imagination. We made up silly games. We hung out together… in person.

Honestly , life would be LIFE without internet :) About the experience . . Well , what's the last time that you spent quality time with your best friends , your childhood friends , talking about all the silly things you used to do back then without constantly checking your smart(?)phone !

What was life like before the invention of the smart phone, it was only ten years ago. But life without one would be very different. Or no mobile at all, no telephones full stop. No electricity, etc etc.
It is a feeling no one in the world can explain it to you. Shut you device and feel the life. :)
There would be no instantaneous, asynchronous communications in the world. Knowledge and information transfer would be very slow and time-consuming.
It would be a lot like the 80s.
